s.text: He's really running on the idea of helping poor people--"strengthening the weak" and "challenging the strong" and spreading the new stock-market prosperity to the least among us.
But I must say, I'm struck by the shift in rhetoric--and what it says about both men's readings of the national mood.
Well, I know Bradley's formal announcement is hardly news--he's been running for president for years now, hasn't he?--but I was struck by the stories this morning.
How do we make the schools really work for poor kids?
He's really running on the idea of helping poor people--"strengthening the weak" and "challenging the strong" and spreading the new stock-market prosperity to the least among us.
What can we as a nation really do to help the poor and the left out?
What can we as a nation really do to help the poor and the left out?
He's really running on the idea of helping poor people--"strengthening the weak" and "challenging the strong" and spreading the new stock-market prosperity to the least among us.
With "compassionate conservatism," he, too, is banking on a sense that the public wants to think of itself as generous again now: generous, caring, altruistic and--yes, let's face it--liberal.
And who exactly should be doing all this--the government or the charitable private sector, or some combination of the two?
